newsitem.title: USA: Argentina reaches deal to protect banking sector.
newsitem.headline: Argentina reaches deal to protect banking sector.

text.p: Argentina's central bank has received commitments from a group of international banks for a $6.1 billion stand-by liquidity credit facility, two senior Argentine officials said on Friday.
The deal, led by Chase Manhattan Bank, would provide for open market repurchases of Argentine government securities in the event of a liquidity crisis among Argentine banks, the officials said.
At a press conference in New York, Argentina's central bank president Pedro Pou, said the facility would be used "only in cases of stress.
"It's like an insurance policy," he said. "We don't anticipate having the accident."
The agreement has a minimum term of two years and a maximum of five years, Pou said. The facility would bear interest at about 2.07 percent over the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR).
The participating banks will receive an average commitment fee of 32.5 basis points per year. The facility will cost Argentina approximately $18 million a year, Pou said.
In addition, economy minister Roque Fernandez said Argentina is "studying the possibility" of a global bond issue in 1997.
